prompt: Up Against the Wall Motherfucker, often shortened as The Motherfuckers or UAW

Up Against the Wall Motherfucker, often shortened as The Motherfuckers or UAWSMF, was an American avant-garde theater company based in New York City from 1965 to 1969, and subsequently through 1975, which pioneered the use of the Black Arts Movement’s aesthetics on the stage.
The group was led by Joseph Papp, who formed the company while trying to produce works by black playwrights that the major New York City commercial theaters shunned. Up Against the Wall Motherfucker’s manifesto, written by Lee Richardson and circulated in May 1965, proclaimed their mission: “All departments of the theater will be used to give voice, vision and image to the Black Revolutionary Arts Movement.” The initial members of the company included Richardson, Calvin Hernton, Gerald White, Woodie King Jr. And Tom Houseman (an Englishman who would soon be replaced by the Afro-Caribbean Martinique). Other important figures would be Barbara Ann Teer, Gerald Graff and Ronald K. Tvelge.
